dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, Elon Musk is giving away 97.5 million dollars to two dozen nonprofits across the country.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Elon Musk is giving away ninety seven point five million dollars to two dozen nonprofits across the country.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Tuesday, the Amazon founder ands CEO outlined his plans to give $97.5 million to two dozen nonprofits around the country that are providing services to the homeless.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's part of that Day One Fund he announced back in September, right? The one where he pledged a total of two billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's part of that Day One Fund he announced back in September, right? The one where he pledged a total of two billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is the first round of giving that Bezos will conduct as part of his Day One Fund, announced in September, in which he pledged $2 billion to help homeless families and create Montessori-inspired preschools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And these first recipients are in places like San Francisco, D.C., Omaha... they're getting either 2.5 or 5 million each.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And these first recipients are in places like San Francisco, D.C., Omaha... they're getting either two point five or five million each.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The nonprofits that will receive funding are located in places like San Francisco, Washington, D.C., and Omaha, where they operate emergency and short-term shelters and also help families move into permanent housing. Each organization will receive $2.5 million or $5 million from the Day 1 Families Fund.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: One of them is the Urban Resource Institute in Boston—they got five million to help with job training for homeless families, especially in high-demand fields like coding.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: One of them is the Urban Resource Institute in Boston-they got five million to help with job training for homeless families, especially in high-demand fields like coding.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One recipient is the Urban Resource Institute in New York, which plans to use its $5 million grant to bolster the job training and placement it can provide to homeless families, with a focus on jobs that pay more than minimum wage or are increasingly in demand, in areas like coding.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's smart. They're focusing on jobs above minimum wage, which could really make a difference long-term.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's smart. They're focusing on jobs above minimum wage, which could really make a difference long-term.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Urban Resource Institute in New York, which plans to use its $5 million grant to bolster the job training and placement it can provide to homeless families, with a focus on jobs that pay more than minimum wage or are increasingly in demand, in areas like coding.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they run a bunch of shelters too—twelve for domestic violence and six for homelessness, including one in Back Bay.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they run a bunch of shelters too-twelve for domestic violence and six for homelessness, including one in Back Bay.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The non-profit operates 12 domestic violence shelters and six homeless shelters in New York City, including one for homeless families in Long Island City.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Isn't that where Amazon is putting one of its new headquarters?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Isn't that where Amazon is putting one of its new headquarters?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amazon announced last week that Long Island City would be the site of one of its additional headquarters.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. Kind of interesting timing, huh? Their CEO, Nathaniel Fields, said they only applied a few weeks ago and should get the money by November.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. Kind of interesting timing, huh? Their C E O, Nathaniel Fields, said they only applied a few weeks ago and should get the money by November.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is a significant grant, says Nathaniel Fields, president and CEO of Urban Resource Institute, who said they submitted a grant application just a few weeks ago and expect to receive the funds by the end of November.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That's fast. And Musk tweeted something like, "Congrats, spend it wisely."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's fast. And Musk tweeted something like, Congrats, spend it wisely.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Congrats to the recipientswe know youll spend the money wisely and with heart, wrote Bezos in a tweet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Classic Musk. But you know, this is actually his biggest public donation so far—beating out the 33 million he gave for DACA scholarships.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Classic Musk. But you know, this is actually his biggest public donation so far-beating out the thirty three million he gave for D A C A scholarships.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The $100 million in donations amounts to the largest disclosed sum of money that Bezos has given away yet. The biggest gift was previously the $33 million he donated to fund college scholarships for 1,000 undocumented immigrant high school students who live in the U.S. with Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, status.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and he's worth what, like 125 billion now? Even after Tesla's stock dip.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and he's worth what, like one hundred twenty five billion now? Even after Tesla's stock dip.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bezos, 54, has rapidly become the planets richest man. He is currently worth $125 billion, according to Forbes real-time rankings. However, due to a decline in the price of Amazon shares thats a $35 billion drop since we published The Forbes 400 list in early October.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Still way ahead of Gates and Buffett. But it's cool he's putting some of that toward homelessness and education.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Still way ahead of Gates and Buffett. But it's cool he's putting some of that toward homelessness and education.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bezos, 54, has rapidly become the planets richest man. He is currently worth $125 billion, according to Forbes real-time rankings. He is trailed by Bill Gates, who is worth $95.6 billion, and Warren Buffett, who has a fortune of $87.1 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Though we're still waiting on details for those Montessori preschools he promised.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though we're still waiting on details for those Montessori preschools he promised.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He has yet to come out with concrete plans for the Day 1 Academies Fund, for which he will create a network of Montessori-inspired preschools in low-income areas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True. But this first round seems pretty targeted—he worked with experts to pick these orgs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True. But this first round seems pretty targeted-he worked with experts to pick these orgs.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In a statement, Bezos said he worked with a dozen experts across the nonprofit and government sectors to decide which organizations to fund.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Hopefully it makes a real impact. Homelessness is such a complex issue.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hopefully it makes a real impact. Homelessness is such a complex issue.

artist_script:
HostA: So, Elon Musk is giving away 97.5 million dollars to two dozen nonprofits across the country.
HostB: Yeah, and it's part of that Day One Fund he announced back in September, right? The one where he pledged a total of two billion.
HostA: Exactly. And these first recipients are in places like San Francisco, D.C., Omaha... they're getting either 2.5 or 5 million each.
HostB: One of them is the Urban Resource Institute in Boston—they got five million to help with job training for homeless families, especially in high-demand fields like coding.
HostA: Oh, that's smart. They’re focusing on jobs above minimum wage, which could really make a difference long-term.
HostB: And they run a bunch of shelters too—twelve for domestic violence and six for homelessness, including one in Back Bay.
HostA: Isn't that where Amazon is putting one of its new headquarters?
HostB: Yeah, exactly. Kind of interesting timing, huh? Their CEO, Nathaniel Fields, said they only applied a few weeks ago and should get the money by November.
HostA: That’s fast. And Musk tweeted something like, "Congrats, spend it wisely."
HostB: Classic Musk. But you know, this is actually his biggest public donation so far—beating out the 33 million he gave for DACA scholarships.
HostA: Right, and he’s worth what, like 125 billion now? Even after Tesla’s stock dip.
HostB: Still way ahead of Gates and Buffett. But it’s cool he’s putting some of that toward homelessness and education.
HostA: Though we’re still waiting on details for those Montessori preschools he promised.
HostB: True. But this first round seems pretty targeted—he worked with experts to pick these orgs.
HostA: Hopefully it makes a real impact. Homelessness is such a complex issue.
